Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Engineering Education through Virtual Communities of Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION

The project is creating a virtual community of practice (VCP) model for professional development that enables faculty members to gain an understanding of research-based instructional approaches and to implement them in their classrooms. The VCP approach builds on: 1) existing face-to-face faculty development models, 2) engaging community of practice models, and 3) rapidly developing web-based social networking and content management tools.

The effort is using a two-tier structure; consisting of a first-tier Leadership VCP that is, in turn, training leaders of second-tier group of Faculty VCPs. The project is conducting two cycles of Leadership/Faculty VCPs within a two-year period, establishing twelve Faculty VCPs with 20 to 30 faculty members each. Five VCPs are initially being established that involve faculty who teach specific introductory engineering courses (electric circuits, mechanics, thermodynamics, digital logic, and mass transfer); while a sixth VCP is focusing on the NAE's Frontiers of Engineering Education (FOEE) members. Each VCP meets weekly using Internet conferencing software and interacts asynchronously through a web portal. In order to identify VCP best practices, the project team is developing methods for characterizing the operation of VCP implementations and for relating the characterizations to effectiveness and impact. Subsequent topics will focus on specific course areas or pedagogical approaches that are selected from those proposed by the community.

The specific project goals are to: (1) establish a knowledgeable community of leaders committed to supporting faculty development VCPs; (2) establish twelve faculty VCPs organized to support participants as they explore and implement research-based instructional approaches; (3) develop approximately 300 faculty members that have gained a deeper understanding of these approaches and have implemented some of them in their courses; and (4) generate new knowledge about the factors that make VCPs effective and identify a set of best practices to guide future VCP implementation.



BROADER SIGNIFICANCE

Engaging faculty members virtually - over a sustained period - moves well beyond conventional professional development models and offers a cost-effective, scalable approach for faculty development. The project is producing a knowledgeable and skilled community of leaders and implementers with a deeper understanding of and experience with research-based instructional approaches. The project is specifically recruiting faculty from minority serving institutions, including those that are involved as principal investigators in targeted NSF-funded projects (e.g., HBCU-UP, LSAMP, and CCLI/TUES). When scaled-up, the VCP approach has the potential to engage large numbers of faculty members in understanding and implementing engaging, authentic instructional approaches and, ultimately, will have a significant impact on classroom teaching practices. Through the involvement of the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE), the premier engineering education society, the project has a significant presence at national engineering education meetings and is also developing plans to expand the VCP approach to other STEM communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When preparing for classroom instruction, engineering educators have access to an extant body of knowledge of evidence-based practices, for instance through the American Society for Engineering Education’s (ASEE) Journal of Engineering Education and papers presented at ASEE’s annual conference. However, while many engineering faculty are aware of proven techniques in engineering instruction, these same educators will often resort to tactics with which they are most familiar (i.e., lecture), despite evidence that alternative instructional strategies are more effective.  

The Virtual Communities of Practice (VCP) supported in this project aimed to address the need for a sustainable, economical, and effective model for faculty development to support ongoing efforts to advance engineering education. Among the benefits of the VCP model are that it is geographic-inclusive, comprised of diverse participants, and provides ongoing, dynamic feedback to its members. This project, in addition to supporting faculty, sought to identify characteristics of the VCP process and experience that would lead to successful outcomes.

Through this award, and in partnership with Arizona State University, ASEE engaged over 175 faculty from 125 institutions across the U.S. We ran nine faculty VCPs (FVCP) split into two cohorts. Each FVCP was led by two experts, whom went through a leader VCP (LVCP) to be trained in managing time and expectations, defining learning objectives and activities, preparing a mid-course review survey, and otherwise fully supporting participants in the FVCP. Each FCVP comprised anywhere from 10 to 30 members and varied in topic (e.g., thermodynamics, circuits, mechanics, etc.) and met regularly online over a two-semester period. In the first semester they were exposed to, discussed, and planned to implement evidence-based instruction practices; in the second semester they offered feedback and support to each other as they implemented changes into their courses. 

Pre- and post-VCP surveys, and in-depth interviews showed a significant positive outcome, suggesting the VCP enhanced the instruction quality of those involved, particularly in that participants adopted evidence-based instructional practices. One community member said of the experience, “my university is small, and I’m the only one currently teaching those courses. I felt like the community gave me a set of people that I felt comfortable to contact with questions related to my field of teaching.” Findings also suggest the VCP model had an impact beyond typically reported instructional outcomes, as the format spawned conversations beyond classroom instruction and practice and into more contextualized explorations of engineering education research. Project results have been documented through seven conference papers, one journal article, and two manuscripts that will be submitted for publication in late 2017.

Having shown to be effective in engineering, the VCP model has been successfully adapted to promote LGBTQ equality in STEM, and we think it could easily be adapted for different content domains across various STEM disciplines. Project information and materials are available at http://vcp.asee.org/
